Yes, there have been numerous studies on how the social hierarchy affects the behavior of individual horses and ponies within a herd. Researchers have found that horses and ponies that are at the higher levels of the social hierarchy tend to have more prominent roles in the herd, such as leading and making decisions for the group. They also tend to have more access to food, water, and other resources.

On the other hand, horses and ponies that are at lower levels of the social hierarchy tend to have more submissive behaviors, and they are more likely to be pushed around by higher-ranking individuals within the herd. They also tend to have fewer opportunities to access resources, and they may be forced to wait for the higher-ranking individuals to eat or drink first.

Overall, the social hierarchy within a herd has a significant impact on the behavior of the individual horses and ponies, and it can affect everything from their stress levels to their ability to obtain resources and their social interactions with other members of the group.
